body_html:
@danieleghisi Indeed, eigen-eigen-334b1d428283 is not a file, but refers to a commit timestamp in the Eigen repository. bazel (magically) pulls a copy of Eigen when building tensorflow. The copy of Eigen ends up in bazel-tensorflow/external/eigen_archive/eigen-eigen-334b1d428283/.

However, if you are trying to use the C++ TF API, I recommend that you start by cloning the code and build rules in tensorflow/cc.

However, if you are trying to use the C++ TF API, I recommend that you start by cloning the code and build rules in tensorflow/cc.
body:
@danieleghisi Indeed, eigen-eigen-334b1d428283 is not a file, but refers to a commit timestamp in the Eigen repository.  bazel (magically) pulls a copy of Eigen when building tensorflow. The copy of Eigen ends up in bazel-tensorflow/external/eigen_archive/eigen-eigen-334b1d428283/.

However, if you are trying to use the C++ TF API, I recommend that you start by cloning the code and build rules in tensorflow/cc.
